text: Anti - <extra_id_0> CD2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> receptor antibodies activate the HIV long terminal repeat in T lymphocytes .

The <extra_id_0> CD2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> T lymphocyte glycoprotein surface molecule mediates both cell to cell adhesion and T cell activation , two processes that are involved in the spread of HIV infection .
Treatment of chronically HIV-infected PBMC with anti - <extra_id_0> CD2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mAb has been shown to induce the expression of infectious virus from these cultures .
In this study we investigated the mechanisms whereby anti - <extra_id_0> CD2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> antibodies stimulate viral production .

We demonstrate that treatment of transiently transfected T lymphocytes with anti - <extra_id_0> CD2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> antibodies results in activation of the HIV long terminal repeat .

Furthermore , <extra_id_0> CAT <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> assays using mutated HIV long terminal repeat - <extra_id_0> CAT <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> constructs and gel shift assays demonstrate that this activation is dependent on the NF-kappa B enhancer .

These studies suggest that interaction of <extra_id_0> CD2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> with its natural ligand , <extra_id_0> LFA-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , may play a role in regulation of HIV expression .
